description: The 'create_clock' function generates educational stimulus images of clocks, either in analog or digital format. The purpose of this function is to provide visual aids for teaching time-telling skills, which is a fundamental concept in early mathematics education.

stimulus_type_specification.title: Available Images: Analog and Digital Clocks
stimulus_type_specification.description: The 'create_clock' function can generate two types of visualizations: analog clocks and digital clocks. It accepts inputs based on the 'Clock' stimulus description class, which specifies the type of clock ('analog' or 'digital') and the time to be displayed (in hours and minutes). The function is designed to create visual aids for teaching time-telling skills, making it a valuable tool for early mathematics education. The generated clocks can be used in various educational scenarios, such as quizzes, worksheets, or interactive learning modules.

details: The 'type' field determines the type of clock to be created, either 'analog' or 'digital'.
The 'hour' field controls the hour to be displayed on the clock.
The 'minute' field controls the minute to be displayed on the clock.
The 'type' field must be either 'analog' or 'digital'.
The 'hour' field must be an integer between 0 and 23, inclusive.
The 'minute' field must be an integer between 0 and 59, inclusive.
The function generates an image of a clock, either in analog or digital format.
The generated clock displays the time specified by the 'hour' and 'minute' fields.
The appearance of the clock depends on the 'type' field: an 'analog' clock will have an hour hand and a minute hand, while a 'digital' clock will display the time in numerical format.

educational_standards.description: Tell and write time in hours using analog clocks.
Tell and write time in half-hours using analog clocks.
Tell and write time in half-hours using digital clocks.
Tell and write time from analog clocks to the nearest five minutes, using a.m. and p.m.
Tell and write time from digital clocks to the nearest five minutes, using a.m. and p.m.

Distinguish between hour and minute hands on analog clocks, demonstrate accurate minute reading using multiplication by fives and individual tick mark counting, and analyze hour hand positioning relative to elapsed time within each hour.
Convert between 12-hour (a.m./p.m.) and 24-hour (military) time and solve elapsed-time word problems that use either format.
